html:
1.14.20  1:48 pm   1.10.20  5:29 am   it feels that way but that doesn't necessarily make it true..does an amoeba have free will? does a person with a tumor pressing on their brain causing them to have uncontrollable violent impulses have free will? i think we feel like we are in control because it's evolutionarily advantageous for us to feel that way, but really we are reactionary in nature. think of any movie right now...did you decide which movie to think of or did one just pop in your mind?

     i would argue everything is like that, including our deepest desires and values, that doesn't make our actions less valuable or important, it just means that ultimately, we as individuals are not the authors of our thoughts and actions, more like witnesses of them.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=202001100529

1.10.20  5:29 am   1.8.20  1:59 am

To play devil's advocate, yes QM implies the universe is not deterministic, but the prevailing interpretation of QM is that the non-determinism is all randomness and probability. So for free will you would need a way for all conscious decision maker beings (arguably all complex life) to control randomness and probability itself

     well, that certainly is exactly what it feels like

     i would argue everything is like that, including our deepest desires and values, that doesn't make our actions less valuable or important, it just means that ultimately, we as individuals are not the authors of our thoughts and actions, more like witnesses of them.

html:
1.11.20  5:20 am   1.7.20  9:47 pm hi I'm an agronomist and my boyfriend is a plant physiologist, when roots are connected plants can communicate with extremely slow electrical impulses. If roots aren't connected, some fungi can transfer the signal. The closer relative the other plant is, the clearer the communication. These messages are usually about the environment and slowly advancing dangers. Quickly advancing dangers (animals eating plants) use hormones and wind. Since these responses are to dangers, plants "feel", but as far as we know, not emotions.

We have the questions page bookmarked on our homescreens, we like to explore your really awesome project of a website together:) we know it isn't a question, but it's 3:20AM and we couldn't help but chime in:) 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=202001072147

1.7.20  9:47 pm   Do you think plants have feelings,

     all together i think they do

      if so do you think they feel how we feel as humans? 

     probably yes i think, all of them together

12.27.19  1:29 am   12.26.19  2:16 am ah, my bad. i will try to communicate better now.
the people i'm thinking about is someone who taught me guitar 2008-2012 who i really like, and someone who is currently my voice pathologist but not for much longer who i also really like. they have also both helped me a ton. would love to be great buds with both of them, give them a taste of their own medicine.

i have this brain, that has not grown in accordance with what i want; it has grown like bound feet. most of it is botched and haphazardly assembled techniques for surviving my family, that i have no interest in. then i'll meet someone really cool that i love being around and have very little to offer them. then i disappoint them and myself and then im lonely and angry.
that is still rough to try and answer i guess but idk if i can do better

html:
12.26.19  1:31 am   umm.  12.25.19  1:27 am    
there is b-sharp. you can cleverly teach all you want, but SEVERAL of my favorite preludes and fugues in Bach's well tempered clavier have countless b-sharps

11.23.18 11:28 pm5.22.17 12:59 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201912250127

12.25.19  1:27 am   Why is there no b sharp?

     because music generally uses families of notes that are not all equally related to each other. the piano, however, uses a full system of notes where each note is equally related to the next, but it's layed out in a way that you can easily skip some of them. the letter names of the notes were based on skipping some of them, because that's generally the trick to getting music to happen. so the spaces in between are called sharps and flats, but like i was saying before, to get that good music sound you wanna skip some notes but not all. and the letters are put on there based on having skipped some notes but not all. so some letter notes are direct next door neighbors (no sharp/flat in between). To explain that in a more real life setting, if you made a system of only 6 letters, with sharps placed between all of them, you would find that playing on only the plain letter keys would produce a very dizzy disoriented sound, akin to a time-warp or flashback scene. but instead the way the letters are actually arranged, this way you can just play the plain letter keys and automatically get something very friendly sounding, like joy to the world, right out of the box


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201811232328

11.23.18  11:28 pm   Hmmm is there any particular reason why some people use Cb to refer to B or E# to refer to F? Coz I've seen this in a couple places (mainly Synthesia)

     it's not some people, it's some situations. if you are in the key of Gb, there is the B note but if you call it B then you have Gb, Ab, Bb, B, Db, Eb. this gets real messy if you try to put it on the staff. to use a key signature on a staff you just flat everything you need and then play the scale, with all the letters laid out. so you can't have 2 B notes, you'd have to keep flatting and sharping it. the same would be true for E#, which would be the last note the key of F# major. if you called if F it would be a mess when you write on the staff, you'd have to keep sharping and unsharping the F


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201705221259

5.22.17  12:59 pm   Why is there no B# or Cb

     there is. B# means C, and Cb means B. you might use B# if you are coming up a scale like F#, G#, A#, C, C#. but you can see if we use B# instead, it looks like F#, G#, A#, B#, C# it looks a little neater because we have 1 of each letter, instead of having no B and 2 C's and have to un-sharp and re-sharp the C. same thing the other way, if you are in Gb major, you might prefer to say Gb, Ab, Bb, Cb, Db neatly so you use all the letters in a row, instead of having to un-flat and re-flat the B by going Gb, Ab, Bb, Bnatural, Db. if you are writing on the staff, the advantage of keeping it scalar become even more clear. i hope that makes sense

html:
12.18.19  4:21 pm   12.17.19  10:40 pm the reason you don't hear about people doing this is because it's not very intuitive or obvious that this is what you should do. but it works, at least for me. even for entirely unrelated fields such as app development. building a bunch of tiny apps that do simple things is a much better way of learning than spending a ton of time on one huge project that i never end up finishing


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201912172240

12.17.19  10:40 pm   so i've written drafts for a bunch of songs, and i like them, but i'm kind of worried they're actually all terrible and suck. should i care? does it matter? should i try and finalize and publish them or just hoard them? idk what to do please advise

     i will recommend this all day, even though it probably doesn't work for anyone besides me. but wow oh wow it really worked for me, to help with this exact problem. if you experiencing too much pressure and fear about the entire song creation process, try doing much shorter songs. you will learn your way around every aspect of the song creation process quicker, and you will be able to easily scale up your operations gradually from there. i have started to realize this probably doesn't work for anyone other than me, because i never hear about anyone doing this. but it has worked so insanely well for me, i owe my entire life to this method
original_html: 12.18.19  4:21 pm   12.17.19  10:40 pm the reason you don't hear about people doing this is because it's not very intuitive or obvious that this is what you should do. but it works, at least for me. even for entirely unrelated fields such as app development. building a bunch of tiny apps that do simple things is a much better way of learning than spending a ton of time on one huge project that i never end up finishing

html:
12.6.19  11:50 pm   12.3.19  5:49 pm i think that line is super catchy, it keeps popping up in my head make it stop


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201912031749

12.3.19  5:49 pm   what did you mean by "too small for the mall" in that one song

     nothing. not good. not a good line. should have been a better line. first 3 lines of that verse were bang on. needed a 4th. first idea was 'too tall', which is worse. 'too small' was a little better but still not good enough. actually it's ok i guess. usually i don't find myself in a position to be slave to a rhyme but that's a rare case i guess. echoing it added confidence i suppose. I just thought of a better line, "guess i'll go home and cry about it" now you may think that's dumb and 'doesn't rhyme' or whatever, but you haven't heard how i would put it musically in context
original_html: 12.6.19  11:50 pm   12.3.19  5:49 pm i think that line is super catchy, it keeps popping up in my head make it stop
